unnormalised: Okay, so my uncle, let's call him 'Sharma Ji' for privacy (wink wink), landed himself in a bit of a pickle. He thought he was being all smart, borrowing his neighbour Verma Ji’s scooter without asking – just for a quick trip to get his favourite jalebis. Now, Verma Ji, bless his soul, isn't one to mince words. Filed a police complaint faster than you can say "IPC 379" - that's theft, folks! Sharma Ji’s now sweating bullets, convinced he's going to jail.

Now, Verma Ji, bless his soul, isn't one to mince words. Filed a police complaint faster than you can say "I-P-C three hundred seventy nine" - that's theft, folks! unnormalised: The thing is, can you *really* get arrested for something so trivial? Technically, yes. IPC section 378-382 covers theft and extortion in detail. Even if it's a scooter for 5 minutes! But honestly, the police have better things to do, like chasing actual criminals, not jalebi-loving uncles. I told him, "Sharma Ji, just apologise, offer Verma Ji some mithai, and maybe prepone your chai time with him tomorrow morning."

unnormalised: My dad, being the retired govt officer that he is, chimed in. He was all, "Beta, law is law! IPC doesn't care if you just wanted jalebis." He started quoting judgements and sections, like he was back in his IAS training days. I think he even mentioned CrPC 41A at some point. Honestly, I zoned out after "cognizable offence".

You never know when Verma Ji might unleash the full force of IPC on your sugar craving! Maybe Sharma Ji should consult Adv. Malhotra, he's quite good, charges only Rs. 500 for the first consultation.
